body:
sorry for the late response. My opinion would be to have dmlFromResource, because
1. provides easy access to DML script in JAR, where ever the JAR is in a cloud environment.
2. consistency with Scala API.
3. having variety of where your DML comes from.
4. dmlFromUrl requires another hop.

I look at it as a progression of DML usage ... people may start with (1) DML as strings, (2) that will become wildly soon as the size of the script grows ... then it goes in a file. Where do i put it if i am in a hosted env. If I put it in git, then it will 1st go in staging area, and I can use it. (3) Once blessed, then a wrapper needs to be developed. 

All that takes time, and blocks experimentation with the script.
LGTM.

@deroneriksson can you please add a unit test for this method? We need to prevent future breakage of code in other projects that calls `stringDataFrameToVectorDataFrame()`.
@frreiss For the new MLContext API, the org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.MLContextConversionUtil class was created to hopefully serve to buffer users from SystemML internal conversion functionality.

My goal here was not to improve the method but to restore the original behavior but using the ml.linalg.Vector import rather than mllib.linalg.Vector. I purposefully was avoiding additional changes to this method since I wanted to minimize potential impact to any user using this functionality.

A. Microbenchmarks.

```bash
git clone https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml.git
git checkout switch_blas_experiment  
mvn package -P standalone-jar
cp target/systemml*standalone.jar SystemML.jar
# Dense experiments
for i in 1 2 5 7 8 9
do
        java -Xmx40G -server -cp SystemML.jar:commons-io-2.4.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -exp $i
done
```

Setup 1: java -Xmx40G ...
Setup 2: java -Xmx20G ...

Both setup 1 and 2 are run of the following machine:

```bash
Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2620 v3 @ 2.40GHz
CPU(s):                24
Thread(s) per core:    2
Core(s) per socket:    6
Socket(s):             2
NUMA node(s):          2
L1d cache:             32K
L1i cache:             32K
L2 cache:              256K
L3 cache:              15360K
```

We ignore first 5 iterations and then run 20 iterations. We drop the best and the worst run and average the time of the remaining 8 runs.

The time is reported in milliseconds.

|                                                |  Setup  | LibMatrix (single) |   MKL (single)    | LibMatrix (multi) |    MKL (multi)  |
|------------------------------------------------|---------|--------------------|-------------------|-------------------|-----------------|
| Matrix-vector 1M x 1K, dense                   |    1    |     953.1612       |    552.7734       |    188.5189       |     466.4393    |
| Matrix-matrix 1M x 1K x 20, dense              |    1    |     15131.62       |    2392.395       |    1231.446       |     1052.258    |
| Squared matrix 3K x 3K, dense                  |    1    |     11682.76       |    1389.884       |    1062.401       |     218.4674    |
| 64 rows x 196,608 columns %*% 196,608 x 512    |    1    |     3047.32        |    484.3707       |    498.5716       |     149.428     |
| 1024 rows x 196,608 columns %*% 196,608 x 512  |    1    |     49041.85       |    5820.965       |    4006.641       |     903.6708    |


Sparse Data: Waiting for help from @mboehm7 or @nakul02 for bug described above

|------------------------------------------------|---------------------|----------------------|
| Squared matmult: 50000 dense                   | 3067.811 (cpmm)     | 3023.844 (cpmm)      |
| Squared matmult: 80000 dense                   | failed with OOM     | failed with OOM      |

@mboehm7 @asurve Setting [spark.sql.codegen.wholeStage and spark.memory.offHeap.enabled](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/376/files#diff-ca6fceb83dfd9c92c83c9bf8de937cdaR219) to false didn't work. Still getting the same error.

Thanks, Niketan. Very good. Couple of questions/clarifications:

1. For the Microbenchmarks, does **dense** mean 100% ? 

1. For the End-to-End, I assume that you had a block size of 1k x 1k, and

1. in that case, in the executors, did mmult run single or multithreaded?
Either way, MKL should be 5-6 faster. But as it does not show any improvement, it says that it is not the bottleneck, and the bottleneck is somewhere else. Just to verify, good you take a look at the stats?

1. Also, choosing a larger blocksize would shift the bottlenecks, and MKL could show some benefits.

1. For the end-to-end algs, I assume that those were single node runs for both data sizes.

1. Given the micro benchmarks, I'd suggest to rerun the numbers, and not use MKL for matrix-vector. 

1. And may be add 1 DL alg to see numbers with matrix-matrix mult in the loop.
for distributed squared multiply, please use pmapmm instead of cpmm; otherwise you're bound by shuffling.

Thank you for reviewing @gweidner!
@bertholdreinwald can you please review this PR ?

>> For the Microbenchmarks, does dense mean 100% ?

No sparsity = 0.9

>> For the End-to-End, I assume that you had a block size of 1k x 1k, and in that case, in the executors, did mmult run single or multithreaded?

Single-threaded calls to MKL by many tasks in parallel.

>> Either way, MKL should be 5-6 faster. But as it does not show any improvement, it says that it is not the bottleneck, and the bottleneck is somewhere else. Just to verify, good you take a look at the stats?
>> Given the micro benchmarks, I'd suggest to rerun the numbers, and not use MKL for matrix-vector.

Please see below chart that shows the performance of MKL without matrix-vector vs LibMatrixMult

|                                 | MKL Total (1Mx1K) | MKL Total (10Mx1K) | LibMatrixMult (1Mx1K) | LibMatrixMult (10Mx1K) |
|---------------------------------|-------------------|--------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|
| L2SVM                           |   27.22           | 159.753            | 29.2576               | 147.763                |
| MultiLogReg                     |   142.31          | 1317.388           | 129.23                | 945.18                 |
| MSVM                            |   78.333          | 286.65             | 68.845                | 426.852                |
| Naive Bayes                     |   22.779          | 154.291            | 22.554                | 173.986                |
| Linear Regression Direct Solve  |   64.602          | 198.84             | 67.82                 | 202.265                |
| Linear Regression CG            |   29.02           | 198.936            | 20.05                 | 157.191                |
| GLM                             |   55.998          | 293.102            | 53.568                | 283.870                |


>> Also, choosing a larger blocksize would shift the bottlenecks, and MKL could show some benefits.

Possible but that might introduce unintended side-effects. So, for now, we should not change the block size.

>> For the end-to-end algs, I assume that those were single node runs for both data sizes.

The 1Mx1K refers to the bar pointed by the black arrow and 10Mx1K refers to the bar pointed to by the red arrow. The cases when SystemML cp+spark backend does not create a SparkContext are annotated with "X". The cases when the input data fits into aggregated cluster memory but not a single node and where perform automatic checkpoint injection are annotated with "Y".

@bertholdreinwald:

Implemented most of your comments (HIDDEN is an output param and was documented).

I didn't implement the resuffling mechanism from shuffle.dml because this script (possibly) reshuffles 2 times. The first time is to reshuffle the input. The second time is to reshuffle the hidden layer representations (if the user asks for it). The second reshuffle is to get back the original order of rows. Essentially, the script ensures that the ith input's hidden representation is produced at the ith row of HIDDEN. If this is not the case then the output will be less useful.

Currently, the script generates a permutation matrix to shuffle the input and then uses the transpose of the same permutation matrix to get back the original order. This requires 1 transpose and 1 mat-mult. The same can be achieved by using the ops in shuffle.dml (store the rand col of numbers, append it, and the order in 'DESCENDING' order I guess) but I'm not sure it guarantees the reverse shuffling. Specifically, I'm worried about randomly generating the same numbers and then trying to reverse the order given these random numbers. The current reshuffling in the script guarantees the shuffling and re-shuffling.

Please take a look when you get a chance.

Approach 1: With Prefetching

The below statistics show that for convnet on 200K column dataset with batchsize of 50, we only wait for fetching of the first batch (~41 seconds). For remaining batches, there is almost zero-wait time. I also did sanity testing using `System.out.prints` and double-checked that Spark job was executed in parallel as conv2d was executing.

```bash
ml.setConfigProperty("prefetch.budget.mb", "300"); // 300 mb prefetch memory

for (e in 1:epochs) {
        i = 0
        for(X_batch in X, nrow=batch_size) {
			i = i + 1
			if(i == 100) {
			   stop ("Early stopping for benchmarks")
			}

		  # Get next batch
		  beg = ((i-1) * batch_size) %% N + 1
		  end = min(N, beg + batch_size - 1)
		  y_batch = Y[beg:end,]
	  ....
	}
}
```

Approach 2: Maxi-batch

```bash
for (e in 1:epochs) {
      maxi_batch_Size = 20*batch_size
      maxi_iters = ceil(N / maxi_batch_Size)
      stopping_i = 0
      for(maxi in 1:maxi_iters) {
          # Get next batch
          maxi_beg = ((maxi-1) * maxi_batch_Size) %% N + 1
          maxi_end = min(N, maxi_beg + maxi_batch_Size - 1)
          X_maxibatch = X[maxi_beg:maxi_end,]
          y_maxibatch = Y[maxi_beg:maxi_end,]
          maxi_N = nrow(y_maxibatch)
          iters = ceil(maxi_N / batch_size)
          for(i in 1:iters) {
            stopping_i = stopping_i + 1
            if(stopping_i == 100) {
              stop ("Early stopping for benchmarks")
            }
            # Get next batch
            beg = ((i-1) * batch_size) %% maxi_N + 1
            end = min(maxi_N, beg + batch_size - 1)
            X_batch = X_maxibatch[beg:end,]
            y_batch = y_maxibatch[beg:end,]
			....
		}
	}
}
```
